claim: If you travel to France and Denmark, you'll need to change dollars into euros and krone.

supporting.text: France uses the euro as its official currency, so travelers will need to exchange dollars into euros.

attacks.text: France uses the euro as its official currency, so travelers will need to exchange dollars into euros.
Many travelers use credit cards that automatically convert currencies, eliminating the need for physical exchange.
Some banks offer multi-currency accounts, allowing travelers to hold euros and krone without exchanging dollars.
Credit cards may charge high foreign transaction fees, making physical exchange more economical.
Multi-currency accounts often require minimum balances or have maintenance fees, limiting their practicality.

supporting.text: Denmark uses the Danish krone as its official currency, not the euro, so travelers will need to exchange dollars into krone.

attacks.text: Denmark uses the Danish krone as its official currency, not the euro, so travelers will need to exchange dollars into krone.
Many travelers use credit cards that automatically handle currency conversion, eliminating the need to exchange dollars into krone.
Some banks offer multi-currency accounts that allow travelers to hold krone without needing to exchange dollars.
Credit card currency conversion often comes with high fees, making direct exchange into krone more cost-effective.
Multi-currency accounts are not widely accessible to all travelers and may require additional setup.

supporting.text: Some businesses in Denmark, especially in tourist areas, may accept euros, reducing the immediate need to exchange dollars into krone.

attacks.text: Some businesses in Denmark, especially in tourist areas, may accept euros, reducing the immediate need to exchange dollars into krone.
Accepting euros in Denmark is not widespread, and many businesses still require payment in krone for transactions.
Even if some businesses accept euros, the exchange rates offered may be unfavorable compared to official currency exchanges.
Official currency exchanges in Denmark provide better rates and are more reliable than businesses accepting euros.
Tourists may not always find businesses that accept euros, making it necessary to carry krone for convenience.
Using euros in Denmark may lead to confusion and additional fees, making it less practical than using krone.

supporting.text: If a traveler uses a credit card with no foreign transaction fees, they may not need to exchange large amounts of cash into euros or krone.

attacks.text: If a traveler uses a credit card with no foreign transaction fees, they may not need to exchange large amounts of cash into euros or krone.
Many small businesses and rural areas in France and Denmark only accept cash, making credit cards insufficient for all transactions.
Credit card fraud is more common abroad, leading travelers to prefer cash for security reasons.
Some credit cards offer dynamic currency conversion, which can result in unfavorable exchange rates compared to local cash exchanges.
Travelers can withdraw local currency from ATMs using their credit cards, avoiding the need for large upfront cash exchanges.
Credit card companies provide robust fraud protection, mitigating the risks of using cards abroad.
